Oh no, how dare Costco stick to their DEI policies and promote inclusivity, fairness, and respect in the workplace? The audacity of them to think that treating people equally and valuing diversity is a good business practice! Clearly, they should abandon all that and cater exclusively to the fragile egos of those who feel threatened by progress. I mean, who needs a company that values employees and customers from all walks of life when we could just have... well, the same old thing forever? Bravo to the complainers for standing firm against the horror of *checks notes* treating people with dignity. Truly heroic.
just like how dare Trump and Musk try to rid the government of wasteful spending--how dare they
Bringing a sledgehammer when a chisel is needed.

It’s almost as if they’ve never heard of irony. Musk, who launches rockets for fun and buys social media platforms on a whim, and Trump, who spent taxpayer dollars on golf trips and vanity projects, are suddenly the poster children for fiscal responsibility? Please. The only thing they’re ridding the government of is credibility. But sure, Kevin, let’s all clutch our pearls and applaud their heroic efforts to "save us" from waste while they live in their golden towers. Truly, the heroes we don’t deserve.

DEI squashes the achievement of achievers and relegates them to non-preferred status, which is racism, bigotry and injustice. ￼ the focus of DEI is to keep reminding us how we are all different… ￼ it's to keep rubbing racism and bigotry in our face. I'm totally against it!

And wow, calling equity "socialism/communism/lowest common denominator advancement" is such a fresh, original perspective. I’m sure all those "underachievers" you’re so worried about are just *thrilled* to hear how much you resent the idea of them getting a fair shot. Heaven forbid we level the playing field for anyone who didn’t start life on third base, right? That would be so unfair to the achievers—like you, presumably—who clearly earned everything they have entirely on their own merit, with no help from privilege or circumstance whatsoever.
obviously you need a leg up to score a job! Not by your merit or abilities to do quality work. Quit whining. We don't gaf..

Ah, Charlie, your incisive commentary truly dazzles with its intellectual rigor and profound grasp of nuance. It’s remarkable how you’ve distilled the complexities of DEI initiatives into such a pithy, reductive quip—truly the hallmark of a mind unburdened by the weight of critical thought. Your assertion that merit and ability are mutually exclusive from efforts to foster inclusivity is as original as it is baseless, a testament to your unwavering commitment to oversimplification.

Costco employees in my experience are exceptionally competent and helpful -- more so than many other large stores of this type. DEI doesn't mean you hire people who are not competent: that's not (at least in my experience) how it works. In academia, for example, DEI just means that hiring committees take every candidate seriously and look carefully at their credentials. After you take each candidate seriously, you still hire the most competent and capable people given the job requirements. That wasn't always so (40 years ago,I know departments where the head faculty members decided not to even consider women who were candidates just because they were women -- that really happened).
